verses.text: How lonely sits the city, once full of people! She has become like a widow, she who was great among the nations; the princess among the provinces has become a slave.
verses.comment: Jerusalem is mourned as a widow—symbolic both literally, after the exile, and spiritually, as the people are separated from God. The 'princess' image points to her previous glory and present humiliation. The city personified as a woman anticipates the Church as bride in the New Testament (cf. Rev. 21:2).

verses.text: She weeps bitterly in the night, and her tears are on her cheeks; among all her lovers, she has none to comfort her. All her friends have betrayed her; they have become her enemies.
verses.comment: Jerusalem's supposed allies abandon her. In prophecy and spiritual reading, this relates to relying on worldly help rather than God's faithful love—a call that resonates for the faithful relying on God's enduring Church.

verses.text: Judah has gone into exile because of affliction and harsh servitude; she now dwells among the nations, but finds no rest. All her pursuers have overtaken her in the midst of distress.
verses.comment: The exile fulfills covenant warnings (Deut. 28:65). Spiritually, it points ahead to humanity's exile from God's presence, and foreshadows the hope of restoration in Christ.

verses.text: The roads to Zion mourn, for no one comes to the appointed festivals. All her gates are desolate, her priests groan, her virgins grieve, and she is in bitter distress.
verses.comment: The loss of liturgical worship is emphasized—a loss of public and sacramental life, reminiscent of the Church's call to persevering, regular communal worship (cf. Heb. 10:25).

verses.text: Her adversaries have become her masters; her enemies prosper, for the LORD has afflicted her because of the multitude of her sins. Her children have gone away as captives before the foe.
verses.comment: Judgment is permitted by God in response to persistent sin. The loss of children is devastating, recalling prophetic warnings and the effects of separation from God’s grace.

verses.text: All the majesty has departed from daughter Zion. Her leaders have become like deer that find no pasture; they flee without strength before the pursuer.
verses.comment: The shepherds—the leaders—have failed, echoing prophetic condemnations of unfaithful leadership and the promise of a new Shepherd (cf. Ezek. 34:23, John 10:11).

verses.text: In the days of her affliction and wandering, Jerusalem remembers all her precious things that were hers from days of old. When her people fell into the hand of the foe, there was no one to help her. Her enemies looked at her, mocked over her downfall.
verses.comment: A tragic recollection of former glory. Such memory draws the soul to repentance and hope for God's restoration and mercy.

verses.text: Jerusalem has sinned greatly; therefore she has become unclean. All who honored her now despise her, for they have seen her nakedness; she herself groans and turns away.
verses.comment: Sin leads to shame and dishonor, exposing the spiritual consequences of Israel’s infidelity—providing a background for the necessity of God’s cleansing grace.

verses.text: Her filthiness was in her skirts; she did not consider her future. Therefore her fall is astonishing; she has no comforter. 'O LORD, see my affliction, for the enemy has triumphed!'
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s lack of foresight leads to ruin. The cry for a comforter anticipates the coming Advocate (cf. John 14:16).

verses.text: The enemy has stretched out his hands over all her precious things, for she has seen nations enter her sanctuary—those whom you commanded not to enter your assembly.
verses.comment: The profanation of the temple highlights both the gravity of sin and the sacredness of worship. This foreshadows Christ protecting the holiness of God’s temple (cf. John 2:17).

verses.text: All her people groan as they search for bread; they trade their treasures for food to revive their strength. 'Look, O LORD, and see, for I am despised.'
verses.comment: Material suffering becomes spiritual poverty. This cry for sustenance hints at the later fulfillment in Christ, the true Bread offering life (John 6:35).

verses.text: Is it nothing to you, all who pass by? Look and see if there is any sorrow like my sorrow, which was brought upon me, which the LORD inflicted on the day of his fierce anger.
verses.comment: This verse is traditionally prayed in Holy Week as a type of Christ's Passion, the Man of Sorrows, suffering redemptively (Luke 23:27-31).

verses.text: From on high he sent fire into my bones, and it overwhelmed them; he spread a net for my feet; he turned me back; he has left me desolate, faint all day long.
verses.comment: The fire imagery illustrates God’s purifying judgment, yet ultimately points to the purifying work God does in the soul through suffering and repentance.

verses.text: My transgressions were bound into a yoke; by his hand they were fastened together; they weigh on my neck. He has made my strength fail; the Lord handed me over to those whom I cannot withstand.
verses.comment: Sin is described as a heavy yoke, calling to mind Christ’s words: 'My yoke is easy, and my burden is light' (Matt. 11:30)—offering freedom through obedience to Him.

verses.text: The Lord has rejected all my mighty men in my midst; he has summoned an assembly against me to crush my young men. The Lord has trampled the virgin daughter of Judah like grapes in a winepress.
verses.comment: The crushing of the people as in a winepress prefigures judgment, but also recalls the image of suffering leading to redemption (cf. Rev. 14:19-20).

verses.text: For these things I weep; my eyes overflow with tears; for a comforter is far from me, one who might revive my spirit; my children are desolate, for the enemy has prevailed.
verses.comment: The lament reinforces the need for a true Comforter, pointing forward to the promise of the Holy Spirit and spiritual restoration through Christ.

verses.text: Zion stretches out her hands; but there is no one to comfort her. The LORD has commanded concerning Jacob that his neighbors should become his adversaries; Jerusalem has become an unclean thing among them.
verses.comment: Even those closest to Israel now treat her as unclean. Throughout the Old and New Testaments, true restoration comes only through God’s chosen means of reconciliation.

verses.text: 'The LORD is righteous, for I have rebelled against his word; listen, all you peoples, and see my suffering; my young women and young men have gone into captivity.'
verses.comment: Affirms God’s justice and the people’s need for repentance—a standard response in both Old and New Testament faith.

verses.text: I called to my lovers, but they deceived me; my priests and elders perished in the city, while they sought food to revive their own strength.
verses.comment: The failure of both worldly alliances and religious leaders emphasizes the necessity of faithfulness to God's true revelation.

verses.text: Look, O LORD, for I am in distress; my stomach churns; my heart is wrung within me, because I have been very rebellious. In the street the sword bereaves; in the house it is like death.
verses.comment: This expression of personal suffering for rebellion illustrates the depth of repentance, echoing the need for personal and communal confession before God.

verses.text: They have heard my groaning, but there is no one to comfort me. All my enemies have heard of my trouble; they are glad that you have done it. You have brought the day you announced; now let them become as I am.
verses.comment: Judgment comes as foretold, reinforcing God’s sovereignty over nations and events—a theme summed up in salvation history.

verses.text: Let all their evil come before you; and deal with them as you have dealt with me because of all my transgressions; for my groans are many, and my heart is faint.
verses.comment: The chapter closes with a prayer for justice and acknowledgment of personal guilt—a reminder of God's readiness to forgive those who confess and turn back to Him through the means He provides.
